title: Guiding India's renewable path: Meet MNRE’s new secretary Prashant Kumar Singh, ET EnergyWorld
text: New Delhi: As India accelerates its journey towards a sustainable energy future, the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) welcomes Prashant Kumar Singh, a veteran civil servant and a visionary leader, as its new secretary. Singh, an alumnus of IIT Delhi with a master's in Public Policy & Sustainable Development from TERI University, has taken the reins at a pivotal moment in India's renewable energy transition.Singh’s career, rich with diverse administrative experiences, includes impactful stints at the Government e-Marketplace where he served as CEO, and in other crucial roles within the Ministries of Petroleum & Natural Gas and Steel. His work crafting the National Steel Policy and engaging in intricate international negotiations at the World Trade Organization has been widely recognized. These roles underscore his proficiency in managing complex policy environments—expertise he brings to his new role at MNRE.Under his stewardship, MNRE is poised to drive India’s ambitious goals to expand its renewable energy capacity significantly. The target is a staggering 500 GW by 2030, focusing on solar, wind, biomass, and small hydro projects. Singh’s approach involves not just enhancing capacity but also ensuring these energy solutions are economically viable and integrated seamlessly into India’s energy grid.Singh’s tenure comes at a time when the global focus on climate change is urging nations to act swiftly and decisively. His responsibilities will include overcoming challenges like land acquisition for new projects, financing models for renewable ventures, and ensuring the smooth incorporation of renewable electricity into the national grid to maintain stability and reliability.The Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE) will also see significant action under Singh. Tasked with reducing India's carbon footprint, BEE will play a crucial role in transitioning industries and households to more energy-efficient solutions, reflecting Singh’s holistic view of energy management.Singh's personal interests in sports and literature add layers to his personality, providing him with a balanced perspective on leadership—one that blends rigorous professional demands with broader life interests. His dynamic approach is expected to resonate well with the younger demographics of policymakers and energy professionals looking to innovate within the sector.As India stands on the cusp of a renewable energy revolution, Singh's guidance is expected to be instrumental. His leadership style, marked by a commitment to innovation and sustainable development, will be crucial as MNRE navigates the complex interplay of technological advancements and regulatory frameworks to achieve its objectives.
